title: Determine whether differences in TLR-responsiveness alter susceptibility to Biodefense priority pathogens using WN virus as a paradigm or responsiveness to vaccination using influenza as a model shared to Semi-Public Workspace (SPW) Project

producedBy.name: Determine whether differences in TLR-responsiveness alter susceptibility to Biodefense priority pathogens using WN virus as a paradigm or responsiveness to vaccination using influenza as a model shared to Semi-Public Workspace (SPW) Project

usesReagent.name: BD OptEIA Human IL-10 ELISA Set
BD OptEIA Human IL-12 (p70) ELISA Set

values: Ambulatory older subjects who are not nursing home residents
Subjects with acute infection (fever and symptoms within 2 weeks of enrollment)
Taking 10mg or more of  Prednisone daily for at least one month
Have illnesses such polymyalgia rheumatica, rheumatoid arthritis, and systemic lupus erythematosus, and at least for the latter two illnesses

Taking other drugs considered in immunosuppression in addition to Prednisone such as plaquenil, sulfasalzine, methotrexate, immuran, cytoxan, tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, other chemotherapeutic agents and other  chemotherapeutic agents
Malignancy other than localized skin cancer subjects
Subjects with a history of previous adverse reaction to influenza vaccine (rash, anaphylaxis)

creators.name: Innate Immune Responsiveness in the Elderly and the Immunosuppressed

values.value: This proposal will explore the hypothesis that altered innate immune responses in the elderly and the immunosuppressed contribute to vaccine unresponsiveness and disease susceptibility.  We will first (Aim 1) assess the levels of TLR expression and the efficiency of TLR responsiveness in younger adults versus elderly or immunosuppressed populations. In addition, we will assess the effect of aging on macrophage migration inhibitory factor (MIF), a TLR-responsive mediator that critically regulates monocyte/macrophage activation responses and downstream cytokine production.  We will then (Aim 2) assess the effects of these impairments in innate immunity, identified in Aim 1, on the efficiency of the response to Biodefense priority pathogens, using West Nile virus infection and influenza vaccination as models. These studies will lead to a greater understanding of how alterations in innate immune responses in high-risk populations such as in the elderly and the immunosuppressed contribute to disease susceptibility and vaccine responsiveness.  Understanding of these mechanisms of impaired host defense will be of general benefit, particularly given the potential for the emergence of new pathogens or outbreaks (including the widened range of mosquito vectors harboring West Nile virus in the United States) or the engineering of virulent or drug resistant agents for bioterorrism.  http://projectreporter.nih.gov/project_info_details.cfm?aid=7337892&icde=23814545&ddparam=&ddvalue=&ddsub=&cr=1&csb=default&cs=ASC

availability: Available for download after registration with ImmPort

dimensions.description: Stimulate human DCs with live WNV and quantify IFN-alpha, IFN-beta, IL10 and IL12 production by ELISA
Stimulate human DCs with live WNV and quantify cytokine (IFN-b and CXCL10) production by Q-PCR

Using live West Nile virus (strain WN 2741), quantify the uptake of WNV in vitro by human DC from the two subject groups. Viral load will be quantified by Q-PCR of WNV E protein from infected human DC cell lysates
Examine mRNA expression of TLRs by Q-PCR in unstimulated and WNV-stimulated DCs

distributions.title: Determine whether differences in TLR-responsiveness alter susceptibility to Biodefense priority pathogens using WN virus as a paradigm or responsiveness to vaccination using influenza as a model shared to Semi-Public Workspace (SPW) Project

acknowledges.name: Innate Immune Responsiveness in the Elderly and the Immunosuppressed

description:
To assess the effects of the impairments in innate immunity identified in the study titled Delineate innate immune responses in populations at risk (the elderly and the immunosuppressed) that are different from the general population on the efficiency of the response to agents of Bioterrorism, using WN virus infection and influenza vaccination as models.

Will also assess these responses directly from patients who had WN virus infection or the influenza vaccine. Will elucidate mechanisms mediating innate immune responses to viral infection using murine models.
